title: What Does HRU Mean? Snapchat, Texting, and More

steps.title: In a text, HRU means “how are you?"
steps.content: In a text, HRU means “how are you?" Whoever messaged you just wants to know how you feel and is saving time by shortening the words. You might see HRU written in all-caps with a question mark, or it can be casually written as “hru”—it just depends on how the person prefers to write it. [1] X Trustworthy Source American Bar Association Leading professional organization of lawyers and law students Go to source HAU and HAY mean the same thing as HRU, though they're less commonly used.

steps.title: On Snapchat, HRU also stands for "how are you?"
steps.content: On Snapchat, HRU also stands for "how are you?" The person who snapped you wants to catch up and see how you're doing. They may send it in a Snapchat message or add it as a caption to a pic they're sending.

steps.title: Send HRU to check in with your friends.
steps.content: Send HRU to check in with your friends. It’s always nice to stay in touch and ask your friends what’s up so you stay involved in their lives. [2] X Research source “Hi Sam! HRU?” “OMG I haven’t seen you in ages! HRU??” “Hey Joey! I’ve missed you!! HRU?”

steps.title: Start a casual conversation with your crush with HRU.
steps.content: Start a casual conversation with your crush with HRU. A crush or casual partner will appreciate that you’re reaching out and staying in touch with them. Send an emoji with your message to make it feel a little more flirty. “Hey you 😊 HRU today?” “Hi babe, HRU at work today? 🙂” “HRU cutie? 😘”

steps.title: Use HRU if you know someone isn't feeling well.
steps.content: Use HRU if you know someone isn't feeling well. It’s nice to reach out when your friends are sick or upset so they know someone cares about how they’re doing. Send them a quick message asking how they’re feeling. Wish them a speedy recovery too so they can feel better. “I heard you got the flu a few days ago. HRU?” “OMG I’m so sorry to hear about the accident! HRU feeling?” “I missed you at school today. HRU? Hope you’re feeling better!”

steps.title: Let the person know how you’re doing and feeling.
steps.content: Let the person know how you’re doing and feeling. Give them a brief update on how you are to keep the conversation going. Them: “Hey HRU?” You: “I’m doing good! Thanks for asking!” Them: “Hey hon, HRU?” You: “Better now that you’ve snapped me 🙂” Them: “You were sick this weekend, right? HRU now?” You: “Ugh, it was a bummer but I’m feeling so much better.”

steps.title: Ask how the person is doing in return.
steps.content: Ask how the person is doing in return. If you want to get the other person talking, be sure to turn the question back around on them. You can ask using HRU or you can spell it out. [3] X Research source Them: “Hey, HRU?” You: “I’m fantastic! HRU?” Them: “HRU doing today?” You: “It’s been tough, but I’m managing. How are you doing?” Them: “Hi sweetie 😘 HRU?” You: “Just missing you a lot 🥺 HRU?”

steps.title: Snap a pic of what you’re doing.
steps.content: Snap a pic of what you’re doing. You could take a selfie and make a face to show the person what mood you’re in, or show off what’s going on around you. Answer their question with a short caption or follow-up text. Send a pic of you lazing on the beach and say, “I’m sooo relaxed rn!” Share a picture of you at work with the caption, “Wish I was home, but I’m okay. HRU?” Take a selfie with a big smile and say, “I’m so excited for tonight! How about you?”

steps.title: HYD or HUD (How’re you doing).
steps.content: HYD or HUD (How’re you doing). Either HYD or HUD make a great option when you’re responding to someone else asking how you are since it turns the question back onto them. [4] X Trustworthy Source American Bar Association Leading professional organization of lawyers and law students Go to source Them: “Hey HRU?” You: “I’m good! HYD?” Them: “I’m good too!”

steps.title: HIG (How’s it going).
steps.content: HIG (How’s it going). Use HIG to ask if someone is doing alright whether you’re starting the conversation or writing a reply. The person may answer about how they feel about a task they’re doing or just mention how they’re feeling at the moment. You: “Hi hi! HIG at work?” Them: “It’s going pretty well! HIG for you?” You: “Hey there, HIG?” Them: “Eh just alright. HRU?”

steps.title: HYB (How’ve you been).
steps.content: HYB (How’ve you been). Ask HYB if you’re catching up with someone that you haven’t chatted with in a while. They’ll want to catch you up on what they’ve been up to and how they’re feeling. You: “Long time no see! HYB?” Them: “Hey! It’s been crazy, but I’m managing haha! HYB?”

steps.title: HDYD (How do you do).
steps.content: HDYD (How do you do). Try saying HDYD if you want to sound a little quirky and old-fashioned. The person you’re sending it to will probably smile or giggle when they read it since it’s not as common as a phrase anymore. You: “Well hello there. HDYD?” Them: “Haha I’m doing pretty good. HDYD?”
